p: Japanese encephalitis is the leading cause of viral encephalitis in Asia, with an annual incidence of 30,000â€“50,000 cases of neurologic disease. JEV is distributed in temperate and tropical areas of eastern and southern Asia and maintained in a zoonotic cycle between Culex mosquitoes and wading birds or pigs ( van den Hurk et al., 2009). Recent geographic extension to Pakistan, Papua New Guinea and the Torres Strait of northern Australia ( Fig. 1 ) may have involved viremic migratory birds or transport of infected mosquitoes by wind, land vehicles or planes. Emergence is also associated with the increases in endemic areas of population, pig production and irrigated rice farming ( Erlanger et al., 2009). The case fatality rate is typically between 20% and 40% with children and the elderly at greatest risk. Effective vaccines are increasingly available and appropriate use should decrease the disease burden ( Solomon, 2006).
